Award.AwardTitle: Measuring Age-Dependent Galactic Abundance Gradients with APOGEE
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the analysis of photometric observations of over 100 star clusters using the Apache Point Observatory Galactic Evolution Experiment (APOGEE). The PI will 1) provide a uniform calculation of star-cluster ages and distance using uniform photometry from large surveys, 2) build a high precision dynamical sample of open cluster tracers, and 3) determine the Galactic disk abundance gradients using a large open cluster sample.

The APOGEE survey will provide a picture of the disk of the Milky Way galaxy that is unrivaled in scope, richness, and detail. In turn, this research will provide critical information for our understanding of the Milky Way in a fully cosmological context. The PI will also make the APOGEE-derived dataset available to the community, as well as train undergraduate and graduate students at Texas Christian University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Despite living inside the Milky Way, we do not know well basic quantities such as its mass, or its detailed chemical makeup at the level needed to fundamentally tie the Milky Way to studies of evolution in other galaxies. The most recent National Academy Decadal Survey of Astronomy & Astrophysics identified key challenges in astrophysics, including "interpreting the 'fossil record' of galaxy assembly; mapping the flows of mass, energy, and chemical elements within galaxies; and characterizing the relationship between ordinary matter and the mysterious 'dark matter'."  Any successful theory of galaxy formation must account for the properties of the galaxy we know best, the Milky Way, including its structure, the distributions of stars, gas, and dark matter, and the star formation history and chemical enrichment. As a result, a detailed, large, and reliable tracer population that spans a significant coverage of the Milky Way galaxy is needed, one of the key tracers used is open star clusters.  However, one of the key limitations currently in the field is large systematic differences in results conducted with different instruments, and different research groups using different analysis techniques. 

This project, the Open Cluster Chemical Analysis and Mapping (OCCAM) survey, has made significant progress towards creating and analyzing the largest uniform catalog of open star clusters.  The OCCAM project is based primarily on analysis and follow-up of data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey APOGEE survey, which is slated to continue through 2025.  The OCCAM project has created a catalog of systematically measured ages, distances, and detailed chemical abundances for more than 20 elements.  We have used this powerful new data set to measure chemical gradients in the Galactic disk, and to determine how they vary as a function of the age and location in the Galaxy.  This project has produced new publically available datasets and new analysis techniques that will continue to be used as new data is collected by the Sloan Digital Sky Survey. The resulting uniform analysis and data set allows the establishment of reliable observational measurements that will constrain supernovae yields and feedback in the time evolution for the LCDM models of Milky Way-like galaxy disks, using the observed, time-sampled chemical abundance gradients of the Milky Way.


This project has provided a significant training environment, utilizing cutting-edge big-data and developing new analysis techniques, for students at TCU's relatively smaller Astronomy program through connection to the Sloan Digital Sky Survey.  The students supported by this grant have been successful in starting academic and industry careers, including: Dr. Ben Thompson, who was a TCU Gradaute student, is now a data scientist at GitHub, Dr. Julia O'Connell who was a TCU Gradaute student, is now a postdoc at U. Concepcion/U. La Serena, now working on the science of globular clusters in the Milky Way with the Sloan Digital Sky Survey, and John Donor, a current TCU graduate student, who is working on science and technical software work for the Sloan Digital Sky Survey.  Also, Cheyanne Sufka, who was a TCU undergraduate that worked on this propject, is currently a Educator at the Frontiers of Flight Museum in Dallas, TX.   The OCCAM project science was also assisted by two undergraduate summer research students who were supported by a TCU REU Site grant.
